Matrices¶

The full docs are below but I’ll touch on some highlights:

  • depends on ndarray. Access the row-major indexed flat array via matrix.flat. This means that any function that takes a flat array can be applied to a matrix.
  • Implements some complex math: solve, dot, svd, and inv
  • has some nice functions for image, including functions to show and save images.

Note

* is an element-wise multiplication. *! is used for a dot product or matrix multiplication. Not like matlab!

Note

The function to show/save images rely on Python, PYTHON_PATH and the pylab stack.

sum(x, dim=-1)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) –
  • dim (Int) – Assumed to be either 0 or 1. Takes all the values in dim and sums them. A value is in a certain dimension if changing that indexing argument selects a different value.
Return type:

ndarray

 
>>> var x = arange(6).reshape((2,3))
>>> assert(sum(x, dim:0) ~== array(3, 12))
>>> assert(sum(x, dim:1) ~== array(3, 5, 7))

Returns the inverse of the matrix. Calls complex_math.inv

>>> x = arange(4).reshape((2,2))
>>> assert(x ~== x.copy())

flat = 'ndarray'[source]¶

The base ndarray stored in row-major order.

index(one, two)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • one (Int, Range<Int>, ndarray) – The row selector.
  • two (Int, Range<Int>, ndarray) – The column selector.
Return type:

matrix

 
>>> x = arange(9).reshape((3,3))
# x = [0 1 2; 3 4 5; 6 7 8]
>>> assert(x[0,1] == 1)
>>> assert(x[0..<2, 0..<3] ~== array("0 1 2; 3 4 5")
>>> assert(x[arange(2), arange(3)] ~== array("0 1 2; 3 4 5")
index_diag(string)[source]¶
Parameters:string (String) – This asserts that this input string must be “diag”.
Return type:ndarray

Gets or sets the diagonal of a matrix.

index_flat(idx)[source]¶
Parameters:idx (ndarray) – In row major order, the elements to take.
Return type:ndarray. Indexes matrix.flat in row-major order. 
>>> x = arange(9).rehshape((3,3))
>>> assert(x[array(0, 3, 6)] ~== array(0, 3, 6))

This is a file, not an actual class.

class matrix.initing[source]¶
array(matlab_like_string)[source]¶
Parameters:matlike_like_string –
Return type:matrix

Interpets the string as a matrix, matlab style. ; is interpets as a new row.

Warning

This currently only works with one digit positive numbers. Negative numbers and multiple digit numbers throw it for a loop. I would recommend using array(Double...).reshape((M,N)) instead.

>>> assert(array("1 2; 3 4") ~== array(1, 2, 3, 4).reshape((2,2))

See also

np.matrix

copy(x, y)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) – The source matrix.
  • y (matrix) – The destination matrix.

Modifies y to contain exactly x.

Warning

This function is deprecated. Don’t use it!

This function is deprecated.

Parameters:N (Int) – The size of the array will be N x N

np.eye

meshgrid(x, y)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • x (ndarray) – One set of elements.
  • y (ndarray) – Another set of elements.
Return type:

(matrix, matrix).

This function evaulates every possible combination of x and y. Very similar to NumPy’s meshgrid.

>>> x, y = meshgrid(array(1, 2), array(3, 4))
>>> println(x)
# prints [1 2; 1 2]
>>> println(y)
# prints [3 3; 4 4]

See also

np.meshgrid

ones(shape)[source]¶
Parameters:shape ((Int, Int)) – The shape of the new matrix. (rows, columns)
Return type:matrix 
>>> assert(ones((2,2)) ~== ones(4).reshape((2,2)))

Return type:matrix 
>>> x = array(1, 2, 3, 4).reshape((2,2))
>>> assert(zeros_like(x) ~== zeros((2,2)))

Operators¶

This is a file, not an actual class.

class matrix.operators[source]¶
dot(x, y)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) – The lhs.
  • y (matrix) – The rhs
Return type:

matrix.

Performs a matrix multiplication between two matrices.

Note

Also callable through *! and x.dot(y)

See also

np.dot, matrix.dot, complex_math.dot

element_operators(lhs, rhs)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • lhs (Double, matrix) – The left hand side
  • rhs (Double, matrix) – The right hand side

The operators + - * / % += -= *= /= < > <= >= == !== all work element wise and act similar to scalars.

Note

Callable through the natural operators (+, -, etc).

Note

== and !== see when two arrays are exactly equal for the incredibly percise doubles. I recommend using abs(x-y)<1e-9.

equailty(x, y)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) –
  • y (matrix) –
Return type:

Bool. true only if the two arrays are approximately equal.

See also

numbers.close

solve(A, b)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • A (matrix) – When multplied with x, this is what the equation equals.
  • b (ndarray) – What the equation equals.
Return type:

ndarray

Solves for x in \(Ax=b\). The same as right-multiplying by the inverse but much faster.

Note

Only works for N x N matrices. Doesn’t have a least squares solution yet.

Note

Also callable through !/

See also

complex_math.solve

Complex math¶

This is a file, not an actual class.

class matrix.complex_math[source]¶
dot(x, y)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) – The lhs.
  • y (matrix) – The rhs
Return type:

matrix.

Performs a matrix multiplication between two matrices.

Note

Also callable through *!, dot(x, y) and x.dot(y)

See also

np.dot, matrix.dot, operators.dot, Matrix multiplication

eig(x)[source]¶
Parameters:x (matrix) – The matrix to find the eigenvalues of.
Return type:the eigenvalues the matrix.

Note

This function does not find any eigenvectors (and should but bugs).

See also

np.linalg.eig, Eigenvalues

inv(x)[source]¶
Parameters:x (matrix) – Finds the inverse of this matrix.
Return type:\(x^{-1}\)

Finds the inverse of the matrix; can be expensive time-wise!

See also

matrix.I, np.linalg.inv, Matrix inverse

solve(A, b)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • A (matrix) – When multplied with x, this is what the equation equals.
  • b (ndarray) – What the equation equals.
Return type:

ndarray

Solves for x in \(Ax=b\). The same as right-multiplying by the inverse but much faster.

Note

Only works for N x N matrices. Doesn’t have a least squares solution yet.

Note

Also callable through !/

See also

np.linalg.solve, System of linear equations

svd(x)[source]¶
Parameters:x (matrix) – The input to the singular value decomposition.
Return type:(matrix, ndarray, matrix)

Finds a factorization such that \(x = U S V\).

See also

np.linalg.svd, Singular value decomposition

Images¶

This is a file, not an actual class.

class matrix.images[source]¶
imshow(x)[source]¶
Parameters:x (matrix) – The matrix you want to see.

Shows the matrix. Relies on Python being found at PYTHON_PATH and pylab stack being installed

See also

mpl.imshow

rgb2hsv(r, g, b)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • r (matrix) – The red color plane.
  • g (matrix) – The green color plane.
  • b (matrix) – The blue color plane.
Return type:

(matrix, matrix, matrix). Returns the HSV color planes.

Note

This function isn’t optimized. If you want to go fast, look at only including the V plane and using max.

savefig(x, filename, save=True, show=False)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) – The matrix you want to see.
  • filename (String) – The filename you want to save at.

Saves the matrix. Relies on Python being found at PYTHON_PATH and pylab stack being installed

See also

mpl.savefig
